Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Broadening Participation. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow and a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Roger D. Tseng is "Investigating circadian clock regulation of essential genes in cyanobacteria." The host institution for this fellowship is University of California, San Diego, and the sponsoring scientists are Susan S. Golden and James W. Golden.

The biological ability to keep time on a 24-hour schedule is ubiquitous, perhaps arising as an adaptation to predictable sunrise and sunset. An endogenous circadian clock endows organisms with this shared ability to anticipate day/night changes and respond by adjusting gene activities accordingly. Understanding how the biological clock regulates gene activities is important because clock dysfunction can lead to metabolic imbalance, abnormal cell growth, and even cell death. The photosynthetic cyanobacterium Synechococcus elongatus harbors the most tractable circadian clock and is an excellent model to study how the clock regulates genes. The fellowship research focuses on how the biological clock of cyanobacteria regulates a special group of genes called "essential genes" that are indispensable for cell survival and are difficult to manipulate without killing the cell. The Fellow is developing a new method to manipulate gene activity of the essential genes without inducing cell death and determining the downstream effects on biological timing. Results promise insights into 1) the genetic regulation between essential genes and the clock, 2) functions of the essential genes as many of them are unknown, and 3) evolutionary advantages conferred by the circadian clock when controlling essential gene activity.

Training goals include next-generation genome editing, bacterial genetics, whole-cell gene expression analysis, and high-throughput mutant screening. San Diego provides an excellent location for educational outreach to veterans with its several military bases, and UCSD has well-established support mechanisms for students who are military veterans. Other educational outreach includes establishing an undergraduate team to participate in the International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) biology competition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During my award to study essential genes of cyanobacteria and structurally investigation of protein complexes functional in heterochromatin formation in yeast, I have completed the following outcome that contributes to intellectual merit and broader impact:

 

Intellectual merit: 

I successfully implemented of the constitutively expressed CRISPRi system in Synechococcus elongatusin year one and year two, I have set out to test my design of controlling the CRISPRi system with the theophylline riboswitch inducible system developed in the Golden lab. 

 

In year three, I started my training to express recombinant proteins in insect cell lines. This training is essential to produce quality eukaryotic proteins for structural analysis. I took steps to prepare the protein complex using this new system. Currently, I am optimizing my protein purification protocols to obtain the required protein complex. 

 

Broader impact:

 

--Successfully competed for an undergraduate training grant from the ?UC San Diego Frontiers of Innovation Scholars Program (FISP).? My co-sponsoring scientist Dr. James Golden and I used this $9000 funding to lead a five-member UCSD undergraduate team to compete in the 2017 synthetic biology competition (iGEM). As a result, our team received the bronze medal from the competition, presented our work at the 2017 iGEM giant jamboree conference in Boston, MA, built a wiki webpage to disseminate our research, and produced a 71-page electronic document named ?A Primer on Synthetic Biology? that contains overview description of various topics in synthetic biology to encourage interests for general public, particularly high school students. The document is available online for download [please see product section]. One of the team members is also an under-represented group in science. 

 

--Served as a lab tour guide for thirteen high school students from the UCSD Scholars Society Overnight Stay Program and twenty minority undergraduate students from the California State University, Dominguez Hills, Undergraduate Student Training in Academic Research (U*STAR) Program and Minority Biomedical Research Support Research Initiative for Scientific Enhancement (MBRS RISE) program. 

 

--Mentored one minority high school student through the UCSD mentor assistance program (MAP) (http://education.sdsc.edu/studenttech/?page_id=879). Throughout the Spring quarter of 2017, we met once a week to work on minor aspects of this proposed research project, provided hands-on training, scholarship opportunities and career advice. At the end of the program, she presented our work in both oral and poster presentations in the MAP program symposium. Afterward, she enrolled in UCSD and is now pursuing a degree in bioengineering.

 

--Served as a judge for the Biophysical Society award at the greater San Diego Science and Engineering Fair, 2017. I gave out one $100 award to the best high school project relating to biophysical research topics. I interacted with numerous students and provided encouraging comments for the great work they were doing.
